course_title: Introduction to Philosophy: What is Philosophy?

learning_outcomes.description: Understand some of the central debates in philosophy (breadth and depth)
Demonstrate basic skills of effective thinking and communication (clarity, relevance, accuracy)
Conduct independent philosophical research and inquiry
Identify, analyse and evaluate arguments or points of view
Understand the role of philosophy in everyday life

assessments.due_date:
5/03/2026 - 21/05/2026

Tutorials run during weeks 2-12, with no tutorial in week 8.
assessments.task_description: Students discuss the set reading for the relevant week. Marks are credited for participation, which includes demonstration of reading the set text and contribution to a community of philosophical inquiry (see marking and criteria). Tutorials run during weeks 2-12 (with no tutorial in week 8) and are face-to-face. This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to write a philosophical essay on a topic from Part I of the course. Topics are specified in detail in the essay task sheet on Blackboard. Word length: 1000 words (includes discursive footnotes but excludes references and bibliography). For this assignment you may use any recognised referencing style, though you must be consistent throughout.

A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted via TurnItIn (on Blackboard); please check that your submission has been received.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

assessments.task_description:
Students will respond to a series of multiple choice questions on both parts of the course. This will be a 60 mins Exam.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
What is Philosophy?

An introduction to philosophy and the course.


Learning outcomes: L05
learning_activities.topic_description: What is Philosophy? An introduction to philosophy and the course.

learning_activities.topic:
10 x one hour tutorials

Choose one tutorial time from the options on Si-Net. Tutorials will be held weeks 2-7 and 9-12.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: 10 x one hour tutorials Choose one tutorial time from the options on Si-Net. Tutorials will be held weeks 2-7 and 9-12.

learning_activities.topic:
What Part of 'know' Don't You Understand? I (Scepticism)

Descartes' Meditations and the problem of knowledge.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: What Part of 'know' Don't You Understand? I (Scepticism)
learning_activities.topic_description: What Part of 'know' Don't You Understand? I (Scepticism) Descartes' Meditations and the problem of knowledge.

learning_activities.topic:
What Part of 'know' Don't You Understand? II (Scepticism)

Ayer's argument from illusion.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: What Part of 'know' Don't You Understand? II (Scepticism)
learning_activities.topic_description: What Part of 'know' Don't You Understand? II (Scepticism) Ayer's argument from illusion.

learning_activities.topic:
Mind over Matter (Dualism)

Descartes' dualism (meditations continued).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Mind over Matter (Dualism) Descartes' dualism (meditations continued).

learning_activities.topic:
Never mind, we are just matter (Materialism)

David Armstrong's materialism on the nature of mind.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Never mind, we are just matter (Materialism) David Armstrong's materialism on the nature of mind.

learning_activities.topic:
Could machines think? (Computationalism)

Turing's imitation game, Searle's objections and Chinese room thought experiment.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Could machines think? (Computationalism) Turing's imitation game, Searle's objections and Chinese room thought experiment.

learning_activities.topic:
Is Science rational? (The Problem of Induction)

Hume's problem of induction and modern responses (e.g. Popper).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Is Science rational? (The Problem of Induction) Hume's  problem of induction and modern responses (e.g. Popper).

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Suspicion

Introduction to 20th century European philosophy with Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud on false consciousness and the fate of philosophy without Truth.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Suspicion Introduction to 20th century European philosophy with Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud on false consciousness and the fate of philosophy without Truth.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Absurdity

Albert Camus’ The Myth of Sisyphus on affirming life in the face of an absurd, meaningless universe.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Absurdity Albert Camus’ The Myth of Sisyphus on affirming life in the face of an absurd, meaningless universe.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Freedom

Introduction to existentialism with Jean-Paul Sartre’s “Existentialism is a Humanism” on human existence, freedom, and our relation to the Other.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Freedom Introduction to existentialism with Jean-Paul Sartre’s “Existentialism is a Humanism” on human existence, freedom, and our relation to the Other.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Gender

Feminist existentialism with Simone de Beauvoir’s The Second Sex and thinking about the philosophical condition of Woman under patriarchy.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Gender Feminist existentialism with Simone de Beauvoir’s The Second Sex and thinking about the philosophical condition of Woman under patriarchy.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Race

Black existentialism with Franz Fanon’s Black Skin, White Masks, critiquing white philosophy and examining lived experience under racism.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Race Black existentialism with Franz Fanon’s Black Skin, White Masks, critiquing white philosophy and examining lived experience under racism.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Embodiment

Merleau-Ponty’s phenomenology of the body in The Phenomenology of Perception and thinking through the racialised body in Hokowhitu’s Indigenous existentialism.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Embodiment Merleau-Ponty’s phenomenology of the body in The Phenomenology of Perception and thinking through the racialised body in Hokowhitu’s Indigenous existentialism.
